item.title: The Point of Dance
item.description:
I can dance if I want to

I don‚Äôt dance. Never have. And i‚Äôm adamant that I can‚Äôt.

To no fault of my loving and accepting parents, I grew up a little repressed.

Some people refer to it as ‚ÄúGifted Kid‚Äù syndrome. Personally, I was never given the title but I over-achieved and felt that paralyzing need to be correct - more than any authority figure could ever place on me. Even at that young age the need to be perfect had settled deep in my bones. And what does one do when their need to be perfect cannot be assuaged? They simply do not act at all.

item.title: It's the Comforts That Make us Feel Numb.
item.description:
I heard once, “It’s the comforts that make us feel numb” - Hozier

And you know what? I think he’s right.

I think the ways in which we save time, the little eases and comforts, the ergonomics of our lives numb us and erode our sense of meaning. Now, does that mean I churn my own butter and sew my own clothes? Of course not, but it does make me think about the little moments that make up my life and how they make up my sense of meaning.

item.title: Surviving Grad School: What they don't tell you in Undergrad
item.description:
Hi! I‚Äôm Nathan. Hope this little Grad School Survival guide helps :)

Check out my other work at Nathanlaundry.com
The TLDR on how to survive your master‚Äôs/phd

Priortize your research, not your grades
Listen to your advisors but know when to take the lead
Don‚Äôt read too much (there is a sweet spot)
Learn by problem-solving
Don‚Äôt leave all your writing to the end

As I approach the end of my first year as a graduate student, I‚Äôve begun to look forward; crafting a path towards a successful thesis and setting up for my PhD. The thing about this kind of reflection is it brings about some alarming realizations. Some of those realizations include: ‚Äúoh dear lord, I don‚Äôt know what I‚Äôm doing‚Äù, ‚Äúwhat the heck do I do next?‚Äù, and ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know, what I don‚Äôt know.‚Äù To remedy this situation, I‚Äôve done what any good academic would do ‚Äî research.
